intro: Campuloclinium siegesbeckioides, commonly known as the Mexican rock nettle, is a perennial herb native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It is characterized by its upright growth habit and hairy stems that often have a reddish tinge. The plant produces small, clustered greenish-white flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate to lanceolate, and have a rough, serrated margin. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or disturbed habitats.
